user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarWait:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarWait(osal_id_t var_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CondVarWait_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarWait:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_CondVarWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    /*
     * note that because pthread_cond_wait is a cancellation point, this needs to
     * employ the same protection that is in the binsem module.  In the event that
     * the thread is canceled inside pthread_cond_wait, the mutex will be re-acquired
     * before the cancellation occurs, leaving the mutex in a locked state.
     */
    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
    status = pthread_cond_wait(&impl->cv, &impl->mut);
    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR 0x0D
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected the provided code fragments: OS_CondVarWait, OS_ObjectIdGetById, and OS_CondVarWait_Impl (and the related macros/typedefs). I found no unreachable code constructs that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1. Reasons:

- OS_CondVarWait: The function calls OS_ObjectIdGetById and then conditionally calls OS_CondVarWait_Impl only if return_code == OS_SUCCESS. Both branches are reachable depending on the return value; there is no code after the final return that is bypassed or rendered unreachable by a prior unconditional return.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Control flow uses conditional returns and an if block based on return_code; each return is reachable depending on outcomes of the called routines. The OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel call is executed when return_code != OS_SUCCESS (including failure from OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex or OS_ObjectIdConvertToken), which is a reachable error-handling path. No statements are located after unconditional returns such that they would be dead.

- OS_CondVarWait_Impl: The pthread_cleanup_push/pthread_cleanup_pop pair is present and surrounds the pthread_cond_wait call as required. The code following pthread_cleanup_pop (the status check and subsequent return) is reachable. There are no constant-condition branches or code placed after an unconditional return that would be unreachable.

- Macros/typedefs: The provided #define and typedef fragments are simple constants/types and do not introduce unreachable code.

Given the above, there are no fragments that appear to be unreachable. Therefore no code fragments need further investigation for Rule 2.1 based on the supplied code.
